segments.speaker: IELTS_Examiner
segments.text: Part 3. You will hear two students called Hugo and Chantal discussing a talk they have just attended at the start of their course in fashion design. First, you have some time to look at questions 21 to 26. Now listen carefully and answer questions 21 to 26. Hi

segments.speaker: Hugo
segments.text: Chantal. What did you think of the talk then?

segments.speaker: Chantal
segments.text: Hi Hugo. I thought it was good once I'd moved seats.

segments.speaker: Hugo
segments.text: Oh, were the people beside you chatting or something?

segments.speaker: Chantal
segments.text: It wasn't that. I went early so that I'd get a seat and not have to stand. But then this guy sat right in front of me and he was so tall.

segments.speaker: Hugo
segments.text: It's hard to see through people's heads, isn't it?

segments.speaker: Chantal
segments.text: Impossible. Anyway, to answer your question, I thought it was really interesting, especially what the speaker said about the job market.

segments.speaker: Hugo
segments.text: Me too. I mean, we know we're going into a really competitive field, so it's obvious that we may struggle to get work.

segments.speaker: Chantal
segments.text: That's right. And we know we can't all have that dream job.

segments.speaker: Hugo
segments.text: Yeah, but it looks like there's a whole range of areas of work that we hadn't even thought of, like fashion journalism, for instance.

segments.speaker: Chantal
segments.text: Yeah, I wasn't expecting so many career options.

segments.speaker: Hugo
segments.text: Overall, she had quite a strong message, didn't she?

segments.speaker: Chantal
segments.text: She did. She kept saying things like, I know you all think this, but... and then she'd tell us how it really is.

segments.speaker: Hugo
segments.text: Perhaps she thinks students are a bit narrow-minded about the industry.

segments.speaker: Chantal
segments.text: It was a bit harsh, though. We know it's a tough industry.

segments.speaker: Hugo
segments.text: Yeah, and we're only first years after all. We've got a lot to learn.

segments.speaker: Chantal
segments.text: Exactly. Do you think our secondary school education should have been more career-focused?

segments.speaker: Hugo
segments.text: Well, we had numerous talks on careers, which was good, but none of them were very inspiring. They could have asked more people like today's speaker to talk to us.

segments.speaker: Chantal
segments.text: I agree. We were told about lots of different careers, just when we needed to be, but not by the experts who really know stuff.

segments.speaker: Hugo
segments.text: So, did today's talk influence your thoughts on what career you'd like to take up in the future?

segments.speaker: Chantal
segments.text: Well, I promised myself that I'd go through this course and keep an open mind till the end.

segments.speaker: Hugo
segments.text: But I think it's better to pick an area of the industry now and then aim to get better and better at it.

segments.speaker: Chantal
segments.text: Well... I think we'll just have to differ on that issue.

segments.speaker: Hugo
segments.text: One thing's for certain, though. From what she said, we'll be unpaid assistants in the industry for quite a long time. I'm prepared for that.

segments.speaker: Chantal
segments.text: Aren't you? Actually, I'm not going to accept that view.

segments.speaker: Hugo
segments.text: Really? But she knows it's the case. And everyone else says the same.

segments.speaker: Chantal
segments.text: That doesn't mean it has to be true for me. OK.

segments.speaker: Hugo
segments.text: Well, I hope you're right.

segments.speaker: IELTS_Examiner
segments.text: Before you hear the rest of the discussion, you have some time to look at questions 27 to 30. Now listen and answer questions 27 to 30.

segments.speaker: Chantal
segments.text: I thought the speaker's account of her first job was fascinating.

segments.speaker: Hugo
segments.text: Yeah. She admitted she was lucky to get work being a personal dresser for a musician. She didn't even apply for the job and there she was getting paid to choose all his clothes.

segments.speaker: Chantal
segments.text: It must have felt amazing. Though she said all she was looking for back then was experience, not financial reward.

segments.speaker: Hugo
segments.text: And then he was so mean telling her she was more interested in her own appearance than his.

segments.speaker: Chantal
segments.text: But she did realise he was right about that, which really made me think. I'm always considering my own clothes, but now I can see you should be focusing on your client.

segments.speaker: Hugo
segments.text: She obviously regretted losing the job.

segments.speaker: Chantal
segments.text: Well, as she said, she should have hidden her negative feelings about him, but she didn't.

segments.speaker: Hugo
segments.text: It was really brave the way she picked herself up and took that job in retail. Fancy working in a shop after that.

segments.speaker: Chantal
segments.text: Yeah, well, she recommended we all do it at some point. I guess as a designer you'd get to find out some useful information, like how big or small the average shopper is.

segments.speaker: Hugo
segments.text: I think that's an issue for manufacturers, not designers. However, it would be useful to know if there's a gap in the market, you know? An item that no one's stocking, but that consumers are looking for.

segments.speaker: Chantal
segments.text: Yeah, people don't give up searching. They also take things back to the store if they aren't right.

segments.speaker: Hugo
segments.text: Yeah. Imagine you worked in an expensive shop and you found out the garments sold there were being returned because they fell apart in the wash.

segments.speaker: Chantal
segments.text: Yeah, it would be good to know that kind of thing.

segments.speaker: Hugo
segments.text: Yeah.

segments.speaker: IELTS_Examiner
segments.text: That is the end of part three. You now have 30 seconds to check your answers to part three.
